articles.summary:
KUTAREVO, Croatia (AP) -- Usually in Europe, when bear cubs get used to
humans, they cannot survive in the wild. And when they grow too big, they're
shot....
articles.title: A bear hug: Croat village shelters bears as good neighbors (The Arizona Republic)

articles.summary:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Dogs are called "man's best friend" - women's, too -
and scientists say the bond between people and their pooches may be deeper
than you might think.
articles.title: A dog's life: study reveals people's hormonal link with tail-waggers (reuters)

articles.summary:
The most far-seeing search ever performed for "Dyson spheres" and other
artifacts of "astroengineering" comes up empty. Where is everybody?


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Alien Supercivilizations Absent from 100,000 Nearby Galaxies (Scientific American)

articles.author: LISA W. FODERARO
articles.summary:
Conservationists say the piping plover, an endangered bird that nests on
beaches in New York State, is threatened by a colony of feral cats, who are
cared for by volunteers.
articles.title: At a Long Island Beach, Human Tempers Flare Over Claws and Feathers (NY Times)

articles.summary:
Thisi a guest post by Aaron Pomerantz, a version of which originally appeared
on the author's website The Next Gen Scientist. Search through hundreds of
citizen science projects on SciStarter to find one that gets you buzzing! A
recent study has revealed thirty species that are new to science living in the
bustling city of Los Angeles. This is really exciting news because we usually
don’t think of urbanized areas as having biologically diverse environments.
Our human-made habitat seems re
articles.title: Citizen Science Helps Discover Thirty New Species Where You Would Least Expect It (Discover Magazine)

articles.author: Bob King
articles.summary:
Brand new images taken on April 10 by NASA's Dawn probe show the dwarf planet
from high above its north pole. Photographed at a distance of just 21,000
miles (33,000 km) — less than 10 times the Earth-moon distance — they're our
sharpest views to date. The crispness combined with the low-angled sunlight
gives Ceres a stark, […]
articles.title: Dawn Rises Over Ceres North Pole (Universe Today)

articles.summary:
Research finds that sustained eye contact between a dog and its owner causes
oxytocin to spike in both--but not so in wolves. What it means remains to be
seen


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Is the Gaze from Those Big Puppy Eyes the Look of Your Doggie's Love? (Scientific American)

articles.author: New York Times: Coral Davenport
articles.summary:
New York Times: A panel of federal judges appeared inclined on Thursday to
dismiss the first legal challenge to President Obama’s most far-reaching
regulation to slow climate change. But in the arguments before the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, lawyers for the
nation’s two largest coal companies, more than two dozen states and the
Environmental Protection Agency offered a preview of what is expected to be a
protracted battle over a regulation Mr. Obama hopes to leave as his...
articles.title: Judges Hear Challenge to Proposed EPA Rule to Curb Climate Change (climateark)

articles.summary:
For many decades, scientists have tried to understand the past by doing as our
forebears did. One important endeavor in what is called experimental
archaeology involves moderns crafting Stone Age...


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Learning to Make a Stone Age Axe Gives Clues to How the Brain Evolved (Scientific American)

articles.author: hcregan
articles.summary: They'll also compete against each other to give more generously
articles.title: Men Give More Generously to Attractive Fundraisers, Study Finds (TIME)

articles.summary:
Individuals in positions of low power perform worse under pressure, relative
to those in positions of high power. However, new research shows that self-
affirmations can effectively reduce the power differences.
articles.title: Self-affirmations may calm jitters and boost performance, research finds (Eurekalert)

articles.author: Discovery News
articles.summary:
The remotely controlled vehicle on a Nautilus Live expedition spies the
largest toothed predator on the planet.
articles.title: Sperm Whale Caught on Camera in Rare Encounter (Discovery)

articles.summary:
An evolutionary biologist fascinated by the way new species evolve, J. Albert
C. Uy has longed to have his research featured in a film geared toward the
general public. But concerns over the way some nature documentaries distort
science always dissuaded him from collaborating with filmmakers.
articles.title: Studying how species evolve (Biologynews)

articles.summary:
On the beach, in the marshes, on the continental shelf and under the deep sea
--and still not all of the oil has been found


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: The Enduring Mystery of the Missing Oil Spilt in the Gulf of Mexico (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
The new image of Ceres that NASA released today is doubly thrilling. It
unveils more of the landscape of this mysterious in-betweener world--an object
classified both as a giant asteroid and as a dwarf planet, a type of object
never before observed up close. But it also taps into the unique significance
of the crescent shape, both to our culture and to our science. The crescent is
one of the most recognizable icons in astronomy. It is the signature element
of the oldest known representati
articles.title: The Fertile Crescent of Space Exploration (Discover Magazine)

articles.author: Bioethics Pundit
articles.summary:
(The New Yorker) - Genetic research has lately progressed so far that, this
year, a group of scientists and practitioners gathered in Napa, California, to
urge a ban on modifying the genetic material of human sperm, eggs, and
embryos, a … Read More
articles.title: The History Lurking Behind “Orphan Black” (bioethicscom)

articles.author: Bioethics Pundit
articles.summary:
(Business Insider) - Some people may be genetically programmed to feel better
after taking placebo pills, while others may only heal with real drugs,
suggests a new review of existing research. The study team looked at evidence
that some people’s … Read More
articles.title: The Placebo Effect Might Be Totally Misunderstood, And a New Finding Could Spark ‘a Revolution’ (bioethicscom)

articles.summary:
Britt McHenry is latest person to be tried and found guilty by social media.
What does that say about online shaming?
articles.title: Why social media delights in ESPN reporter's tirade (CBS News)
